Literature Review: The Hubble tension, a discrepancy between the cosmic expansion rate measured directly from observations and that inferred from the standard Lambda Cold Dark Matter (ΛCDM) model, has become one of the most pressing issues in modern cosmology. This review aims to explore the nature of this tension, recent observational developments, and potential solutions, with a focus on early Universe modifications, particularly early dark energy models.The Hubble constant (H0) is a fundamental parameter in cosmology, representing the current expansion rate of the Universe. Direct measurements of H0 using local distance indicators, such as Cepheid variables and Type Ia supernovae, consistently yield higher values than those inferred from cosmic microwave background (CMB) observations assuming the ΛCDM model. Riess et al. (2019) reported a local H0 value of 74.03 ± 1.42 km s^-1 Mpc^-1, while Planck Collaboration (2020) derived a value of 67.4 ± 0.5 km s^-1 Mpc^-1 from CMB data, resulting in a tension of more than 4σ.The persistence and significance of this discrepancy have led researchers to explore various explanations, including potential systematic errors in measurements and modifications to the standard cosmological model. Verde et al. (2019) conducted a comprehensive review of proposed systematic errors and found that they are insufficient to fully resolve the tension, suggesting that a solution may require new physics beyond ΛCDM.Early Universe modifications have emerged as promising candidates to address the Hubble tension. These models aim to alter the pre-recombination physics of ΛCDM while maintaining consistency with other cosmological observations. Poulin et al. (2019) introduced the concept of early dark energy (EDE) as a potential solution. In this scenario, a new form of dark energy contributes significantly to the energy density of the Universe before recombination, modifying the sound horizon and allowing for a higher H0 value consistent with local measurements.The EDE model has gained attention due to its ability to alleviate the Hubble tension while preserving the success of ΛCDM in explaining other cosmological phenomena. Smith et al. (2020) further developed the EDE model, demonstrating its compatibility with a wide range of cosmological data, including CMB, baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO), and large-scale structure observations.However, challenges remain for EDE and other early Universe modifications. Ivanov et al. (2020) found that including additional large-scale structure data can constrain the effectiveness of EDE in resolving the Hubble tension. This highlights the importance of considering multiple cosmological probes when evaluating potential solutions.The search for a resolution to the Hubble tension has spurred advancements in observational techniques and data analysis. Freedman et al. (2020) presented an independent measurement of H0 using the tip of the red giant branch (TRGB) method, obtaining a value intermediate between the local and CMB-based results. This measurement underscores the complexity of the Hubble tension and the need for diverse, independent approaches to cosmic distance measurements.Future observations and experiments hold promise for further constraining early Universe models and potentially resolving the Hubble tension. The Simons Observatory, as described by Ade et al. (2019), will provide high-precision CMB measurements that could help distinguish between different early Universe scenarios. Additionally, gravitational wave observations from events with electromagnetic counterparts, as discussed by Chen et al. (2018), offer a new, independent method for measuring H0 and testing cosmological models.As the field progresses, it is crucial to consider the broader implications of early Universe modifications on our understanding of cosmology and fundamental physics. Di Valentino et al. (2021) explored the connections between the Hubble tension and other cosmological puzzles, such as the nature of dark matter and dark energy, emphasizing the potential for a unified solution to multiple outstanding issues in physics.In conclusion, the Hubble tension remains a significant challenge in modern cosmology, with early Universe modifications, particularly early dark energy models, emerging as promising avenues for resolution. As observational techniques continue to improve and new data become available, the coming years are likely to bring further insights into this cosmic conundrum and potentially reshape our understanding of the Universe's evolution and composition.
